name: Bern (le Carré)
description: The Swiss capital city acting as a neutral ground and a discreet operational setting in 'Smiley’s People'.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Bern holds a special place in 'Smiley’s People' as a neutral territory amidst the Cold War’s ideological battlefields. Its reputation for neutrality and discretion makes it an ideal location for secret meetings and subtle intelligence work.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: The city is depicted with its historic medieval center, narrow streets lined with sandstone facades, and the Aare River winding nearby. This blend of old-world charm and modern administrative facilities reflects the dual nature of transparency and secrecy essential to espionage settings.

content.title: History
content.body: Bern historically served as Switzerland’s political heart, known for its diplomatic neutrality, especially during the Cold War. In the novel, it represents a vital crossroads where East and West agents maneuver carefully to avoid public attention.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: Within 'Smiley’s People', Bern is crucial for clandestine exchanges between operatives and acts as a symbolic crossroads for characters seeking resolution or betrayal, highlighting the complexities of neutrality during geopolitical tension.
